questions.question_text:
A cybersecurity analyst was hired to resolve a security issue within a company after it was reported that many employee account passwords had been compromised. Upon investigating the incident, the cybersecurity analyst found that a brute force attack was launched against the company.
Which of the following remediation actions should the cybersecurity analyst recommend to senior management to address these security issues?

discussion.content: b is the correct one on this because reuse would not protect if you can still have the same passport policy. So if you have multifa then having your password gives attacker not much
my previous comment applies to B not C

GPO with users using more complex passwords will only make it harder/longer with respect to time, for attackers to brute force their password. Same with security training, and its not guarantee that users will apply what they learned with security awareness.

However, as for multi-factor authentication, even though their passwords got cracked/brute-forced, there is another factor/context/identity which needs to be provided before the attack is successful.

Letter B is still the best choice among all choices.

choices.A: Prohibit password reuse using a GPO.

discussion.content: what is the correct answer i think its DF

comments.content: D and F 100%. Everything else would be done on internal stuff. But D and F would be external resources
D and F for sure. What the question is getting at is the OSINT process and a non-technical answer.

discussion.content: I think the keyword here is externally(publicly) which is available to anybody. Answers are D F.
i agree with D & F
I went for Fingerprinting and banner grabbing. However, after reading these comments D and F make better sense.
I think D & F are correct. The way I understand this question is that's it related to passive reconnaissance. A, B, C, E and G are all related to systems owned by the organisation itself.
This question was in the exam :)

I'm leaning towards A&C (Fingerprinting and Banner grabbing). Fingerprinting is a way of identifying a visiting user or device through conf settings.
the latter is how you get info about services running on open ports of a computer on a network.

I also believe A and C are correct. I think this question is identifying the difference between pen testing and security analysis. The SecAn would be looking for data based on reports to catch as many vulnerabilities as possible in one project. A pen tester might seek out social media vulnerabilities. But it’s not as efficient, and that information is harder to find, unless you’ve done some social engineering.
AC - I think

comments.content: Could be, but the question specifies what is exposed externally. Banner grabbing would be external, but not the best way to determine what is exposed externally.

discussion.content: I think this is fingerprinting and banner grabbing

questions.question_text: An analyst has initiated an assessment of an organization's security posture. As a part of this review, the analyst would like to determine how much information about the organization is exposed externally. Which of the following techniques would BEST help the analyst accomplish this goal? (Choose two.)

Scan results identify critical Apache vulnerabilities on a company's web servers. A security analyst believes many of these results are false positives because the web environment mostly consists of Windows servers.
Which of the following is the BEST method of verifying the scan results?

choices.B: Refer to the identified servers in the asset inventory.
choices.A: Run a service discovery scan on the identified servers.
choices.C: Perform a top-ports scan against the identified servers.
choices.D: Review logs of each host in the SIEM.

discussion.content: I will go with A also, asset inventory might be outdated. but on a second thought, some vulnerability scanners also have features that can automatically discover and classify asset
asset inventory results might be old, so running service discovery would give us that we are seeking here
Wouldn't it be better to refer to the asset inventory? :/

comments.content: Agree. Running a service discovery scan may find the same Apache service running on the servers and would not really help you in any way. Referring to the asset inventory is the best choice here i think.

discussion.content: SLA is the answer

It does not matters if it talks about 'expectations' of requirements. PCI DSS is mandated by auto-regulated bodies. It is not something that you can go about as you wish. SLA would ensure scans are done in due time and with a pre-approved scanner every 3 months.
MOU is the answer

The answer sounds like MOU, I got this information directly from COM001A - Official CompTIA Study Guide for Cybersecurity Analyst (CySA+) (Exam CS0-001)

Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) - usually a preliminary or exploratory agreement to express an intent to work together. An MOU is not usually intended to have the effect of a binding contract but must be carefully drafted so as not to create binding conditions.

Service Level Agreement (SLA) - a contractual agreement setting out the detailed terms under which an ongoing service is provided. The terms of an SLA are binding on both parties and in any dispute only a strict interpretation of the terms will be considered by a court.

MOU is answer. The keyword here would be EXPECTATIONS.
Wheras with a SLA we have a legally binding agreement.

https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mou.asp <- CTRL + F "expectations"
I would think this should be MOU, as it is just expressing expectations, not providing direct guidelines.

comments.content:
MOU's are less formal than SLA's: https://blogs.getcertifiedgetahead.com/security-interoperability-agreements/#:~:text=An%20MOU%20expresses%20an%20understanding,does%20not%20include%20monetary%20penalties.

I hope that helps.

questions.question_text:
A retail corporation with widely distributed store locations and IP space must meet PCI requirements relating to vulnerability scanning. The organization plans to outsource this function to a third party to reduce costs.
Which of the following should be used to communicate expectations related to the execution of scans?
A cybersecurity professional wants to determine if a web server is running on a remote host with the IP address 192.168.1.100. Which of the following can be used to perform this task?

discussion.content: the nmap command may not return correct results if the webs server is running on a non-standard port
Confirmed that this nmap. This can be netcat command in letter A is wrong.

comments.content: yeah youre right but its nmap
nmap correct, netcat command is for listen mode
